conclusion: Determine the particle velocity v1 when it reaches the collection device.
Consider conditions under which the particle is emitted from source S and moves in the magnetic field until it collides with the collection device along the positive x-axis.
The charged particle in the magnetic field experiences a Lorentz force F = qvB.
For circular motion, Lorentz force provides the centripetal force, giving equation qvB = mv^2/r.
Solving for the radius r gives r = mv/(qB).
Given the charge-to-mass ratio q/m = 2 x 10^6 C/kg.
Rewrite the radius equation as r = v/(q/m B) = v/(2 x 10^6)(5 x 10^-3) = v/10^4.
The particle source S is located 1.2 meters above the origin O.
For the particle to hit the collection device on the positive x-axis, the radius of its circular path must be such that it intersects the x-axis at O.
The radius r must be 1.2 meters because the particle moves directly downwards to the x-axis.
Using the radius equation r = v/10^4, set 1.2 = v/10^4.
Solving for v gives v = 1.2 x 10^4 m/s.
The particle velocity v1 when it reaches the collection device is 1.2 x 10^4 m/s.
